title: Community Tools Maintenance/Updates
description: Catalyst is constantly changing and evolving. Without maintenance and updates, useful Community Tools will become outdated and useless.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is part of a number of proposals intended to fund the activities of the AIM team, which stands behind important tools used by the Catalyst community.

Knowing about the importance of not only developing, but also 'Application Lifecycle Managing' and maintaining any kind of software tools, I think this is of high practical importance. 

Since this proposal is about updating and maintaining already used tools, positive impact, user-acceptance and user-adoption are highly secured.
f6_assessments.q1:
Behind this proposal are major members of the AIM team, which is the team driving the voter-tool, CA-tool, vCA-Tool and the Community Landing Page. 

Due to the fact that most of this developments are already available and the funding is mainly about improvements and maintenance, there is a very high feasibility that the goals can be reached
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal comes from a well-integrated core-contributor-team closely linked with the CATALYST process.

The activities, roadmap, costs and milestones are proerly listed. Auditability is therefore easily possible.

The asked amount is rather small and very reasonable.

f6_assessments.q0: These tools have already had a positive impact towards productivity and provide a means to track the amount of assessments a proposal has received. So it helps tremendously in achieving the minimum assessment quota per proposal and enables this community to iterate more efficiently fund after fund.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers are respected members of the community. One of them is a Catalyst Circle CA representative. So there is a lot of relevant experience present. In terms of implementation and likeliness to succeed, the tools are already developed and operational.
f6_assessments.q2:
As expected from people that aim to make tools for a community in order to improve proposal quality, this proposal is a good example. 
There is a roadmap, a plan, enough information to verify and the fund request is more than reasonable.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes. This proposal is founded on the acknowledgement that the existing community tools created by the proposing team have demonstrably contributed to distributed decision making within Catalyst and Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: Yes, the creation, quality, and usefulness of the existing community tools demonstrate the capacity of the team to implement this proposal successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is not extremely detailed. Nevertheless, the past success of this team within Catalyst regarding proposal funding and execution, and the engagement of the team members with Catalyst and Cardano provide more than enough confidence that the project progress and success can be adequately audited. I would suggest that for the implementation and for future proposals the team can improve the detail of the information provided for auditing as an example for other teams and under the assumptions that in the future all teams (even anonymous or anonymized teams), should be treated equally, and that future advisors and voters should not rely on their previous knowledge of the Cardano ecosystem to be able to adequately assess proposals and teams. Congratulations, and great success!

f6_assessments.q0: Absolutely - these tools are pivotal for the community to work effectively with the increasing workload. To be able to organize the work the tools are critical - for instance to point out which proposals did not receive enough assessments and should be considered by a CA for review. With about 800 proposals these tools cannot be substituted by manually looking through the load of proposals. Basically, these tools facilitate decision-making and need to be funded and developed.
f6_assessments.q1: Given that the developers created the tools that are in use and have been used successfully in previous funds, naturally, the experience and the likelyhood of implementation is very high for these proposers. The financial budget is broken down very thoroughly and in my opinion the proposers are very fair with their budget in favor of the Catalyst community and their engagement in and commitment to this community can be seen as very high. The roadmap is very exact and feasable.
f6_assessments.q2: Yes. Both the roadmap and success criteria (CA-tool, vCAtool, Proposer Tool) are auditable as well as feasable. Additionally, the team can be reached through various channels across the Catalyst community, they offer support and answer questions constantly and they are actively asking for feedback from the community to develop/iterate the tools, hence creating and developing the tools with the community in mind, another important aspect of distributed decision making.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem and solution presented are clear and within the scope of the challenge.

The AIM tools have been very important in the decision making of all those actively involved in Catalyst, CAs, vCAs, proposers and voters.

The established goals indicate a great impact on Fund6 and Fund7. I would only recommend the inclusion of metrics/KPIs that can help the indication of impact. e.g. Number of CAs, vCAs and proposers that used the tool, % of those who used it vs % of those who did not used it...

Despite this point, my score remains 5, as the set of items and information is too weighty for just a 4.
f6_assessments.q1:
The trio of AIM members have been developing these tools since Fund4 and have already demonstrated their skills and aptitude for further development.
There is a detailed and objective timeline, indicating that the tools will be available on time.
There is a very detailed and reasonable budget breakdown.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is clarity on the problem, solution and alignment with the challenge.
There is an objective roadmap with defined dates for tool updates.
Metrics and KPIs were not included, which makes the audit more subjective.

f6_assessments.q0: As this is my first fund as a community advisor using these tools had a positive impact on me. It was the nudge that I needed to start my journey in the community. Looking at this proposal I can only say it matches the challenge entirely.
f6_assessments.q1: The plan to further develop the community tools is clear. They give a clear explanation of what is planned in the future. The roadmap has delivery dates, which are soon but since the tools already exist I don't see any obstacles to prevent the delivery. The budget breakdown is a perfect example of how it should be. I highly see this being implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: Given the clear state of where the project already is and the information that is given in this proposal, I only see progress and success further down the road. I would recommend for future proposals that you state some metrics. Like how many times are the tools used to be considered successful?

solution: Continuously update the already funded (Fund5) Community Tools (CA/vCA/Proposer-QA Tools) during 2 more Funds (6 and 7).
experience: Community Landing page, Community Advisors since Fund3, Implementation of Yellow/Red Cards system for reviewing assessments, Full Stack Dev.
